project_metadata.paper_title: Deploying an Offline, Multi-User, Mobile System for Digital Recording in the Perachora Peninsula, Greece
project_metadata.research_context: Mobile GIS deployment paper testing FAIMS Mobile platform for legacy feature verification and pedestrian survey at Perachora Peninsula Archaeology Project (PPAP), Greece

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS Mobile was deployed at PPAP for systematic pedestrian surface survey and legacy feature verification
evidence.verbatim_quote: This article discusses the deployment of mobile data capture software developed by the Field Acquired Information Management Systems project (FAIMS Mobile) to document systematic pedestrian surface survey and legacy feature verification at the Perachora Peninsula Archaeology Project (PPAP), Greece, in 2020.

evidence.evidence_text: Two existing customizations from FAIMS library were reused and adapted for the two workflows
evidence.verbatim_quote: We reused and adapted two existing customizations from the FAIMS library for comprehensive digital recording of two workflows, integrating a collection of structured data, geospatial data, photos, and text.

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS Mobile required only modest hardware
evidence.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile required only modest hardware but supported offline setup, synchronization, and data export, allowing PPAP to deploy it despite unreliable internet access.

evidence.evidence_text: The system supported offline setup, synchronization, and data export
evidence.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile required only modest hardware but supported offline setup, synchronization, and data export, allowing PPAP to deploy it despite unreliable internet access.

evidence.evidence_text: PPAP had unreliable internet access
evidence.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile required only modest hardware but supported offline setup, synchronization, and data export, allowing PPAP to deploy it despite unreliable internet access.

evidence.evidence_text: All collected data was available daily for planning
evidence.verbatim_quote: All collected data was available daily for planning, and a comprehensive dataset adhering to Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable (FAIR) data standards was ready for analysis with only a few hours of processing after fieldwork.

evidence.evidence_text: A comprehensive FAIR dataset was ready for analysis with only a few hours of processing after fieldwork
evidence.verbatim_quote: All collected data was available daily for planning, and a comprehensive dataset adhering to Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable (FAIR) data standards was ready for analysis with only a few hours of processing after fieldwork.

evidence.evidence_text: Field research disciplines, including archaeology, often fail to make data available

location.section: The Challenge of Digital Field Data Collection

evidence.verbatim_quote: Field research disciplines, including archaeology, often fail to make data available, compromising the integrity of results (McNutt et al. 2016).

evidence.evidence_text: Despite mature data repositories, FAIR field research data publication remains the exception rather than the rule

location.section: The Challenge of Digital Field Data Collection

evidence.verbatim_quote: Despite mature data repositories, the publication of Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable (FAIR) field research data remains the exception rather than the rule.

evidence.evidence_text: Archaeology suffers from 'small science' data problems: diverse, idiosyncratic, unpredictable data; variable methodologies; lack of data standards; limited resources

location.section: The Challenge of Digital Field Data Collection

evidence.verbatim_quote: Archaeology suffers from "small science" data problems: the data is diverse, idiosyncratic, and unpredictable; archaeologists employ variable methodologies and recording systems for the same activities; the discipline lacks widely adopted data standards; and, most projects have limited resources (Kansa and Bissell 2010; Borgman 2015).

evidence.evidence_text: Archaeology has prioritized methodological innovation and publication of results over data stewardship and reuse

location.section: The Challenge of Digital Field Data Collection

evidence.verbatim_quote: Like other disciplines, archaeology has prioritized methodological innovation and publication of results over data stewardship and reuse (McNutt et al. 2016, 1025).

evidence.evidence_text: Archaeologists have often 'made do' with software designed for other tasks or built one-off solutions, leading to duplication of effort, under-resourced development, and sustainability problems

location.section: The Challenge of Digital Field Data Collection

evidence.verbatim_quote: Archaeologists have often "made do" with software designed for other tasks or built one-off solutions for individual projects, leading to the duplication of effort, under-resourced development, and infrastructure sustainability problems.

evidence.evidence_text: Archaeologists often organize information idiosyncratically using ad-hoc mix of paper, digital fragments, and bespoke databases; long-established projects have data from multiple recording system generations

location.section: The Challenge of Digital Field Data Collection

evidence.verbatim_quote: archaeologists often organize information idiosyncratically, using an ad-hoc mix of paper, digital data fragments from various applications, and bespoke databases... Long-established projects may have data produced by several generations of recording systems.

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Identical support pattern (C012, C013). Related aspects of same problem (idiosyncratic + multi-generational data) from same paragraph. Assessment would evaluate together as compound evidence of data management challenge.

evidence.evidence_text: Non-integrated approach demands time-consuming reconciliation and cleaning efforts

location.section: The Challenge of Digital Field Data Collection

evidence.verbatim_quote: This nonintegrated approach demands time-consuming reconciliation and cleaning efforts to produce comprehensive and consistent datasets.

evidence.evidence_text: Even where datasets exist, they are often poorly documented and difficult to reuse

location.section: The Challenge of Digital Field Data Collection

evidence.verbatim_quote: Even where datasets exist, they are often poorly documented and difficult to reuse.

evidence.evidence_text: Data deficiencies undermine research integrity and inhibit independent analyses, application of new techniques, and synthesis across studies

location.section: The Challenge of Digital Field Data Collection

evidence.verbatim_quote: These deficiencies not only undermine research integrity, but also inhibit independent analyses of primary data, the application of new techniques to old datasets, and the synthesis of data from multiple studies to address disciplinary grand challenges (Kintigh 2006, 567; Kintigh et al. 2014; McNutt et al. 2016).

evidence.evidence_text: Critical data and metadata must be captured in the field or risk being lost

location.section: The Challenge of Digital Field Data Collection

evidence.verbatim_quote: Critical data and metadata must be captured in the field or risk being lost (Buck 2015; McNutt et al. 2016; Digital Curation Centre 2020).

evidence.evidence_text: Field data collection requires systems that work offline, accommodate wide range of methods and data, keep pace with mobile fieldwork, and adapt to unexpected discoveries

location.section: The Challenge of Digital Field Data Collection

evidence.verbatim_quote: Such data collection requires systems that can work offline, accommodate a wide range of methods, data, and metadata, keep pace with highly mobile fieldwork, and adapt to unexpected discoveries.

evidence.evidence_text: Mass-market software designed primarily for other purposes is often a poor fit for field research requirements

location.section: The Challenge of Digital Field Data Collection

evidence.verbatim_quote: Mass-market software designed primarily for other purposes is often a poor fit for such requirements, demanding that researchers make significant compromises.

evidence.evidence_text: Challenges lead to a digital bottleneck during fieldwork that impedes later analysis and publication of data

location.section: The Challenge of Digital Field Data Collection

evidence.verbatim_quote: Together, these challenges lead to a digital bottleneck during fieldwork that impedes the later analysis and publication of data.

evidence.evidence_text: PPAP is a three-year synergasia (joint Greek-Australian project) co-directed by Kasimi and Lupack, granted permit by Greek Ministry of Culture to survey ca. 30 km² around Sanctuary of Hera

location.section: Deployment Context: The Perachora Peninsula Archaeology Project

evidence.verbatim_quote: PPAP is a three-year synergasia (a joint Greek-Australian project) co-directed by Panagiota Kasimi (Director of the Ephorate of Antiquities of the Corinthia) and Susan Lupack (Macquarie University)... The Greek Ministry of Culture granted PPAP a permit to survey ca. 30 km2 around the Sanctuary of Hera

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Identical support pattern (C019). Complementary project characteristics from same paragraph. Assessment would evaluate together as complete project description.

evidence.evidence_text: PPAP survey region encompasses known sites dating from Early Helladic through Byzantine eras

location.section: Deployment Context: The Perachora Peninsula Archaeology Project

evidence.verbatim_quote: In addition to the sanctuary, this region encompasses known sites of archaeological interest dating from the Early Helladic through the Byzantine eras.

evidence.evidence_text: 2020 season was exploratory in nature and limited to three weeks

location.section: Deployment Context: The Perachora Peninsula Archaeology Project

evidence.verbatim_quote: The 2020 season was exploratory in nature and limited to three weeks.

evidence.evidence_text: 2020 season concentrated on western end of peninsula documenting features and artifacts associated with town near sanctuary

location.section: Deployment Context: The Perachora Peninsula Archaeology Project

evidence.verbatim_quote: It concentrated on the western end of the peninsula (see Figures 1, 2), documenting features and artifacts associated with the town near the sanctuary.

evidence.evidence_text: Significance of town with domestic structures and extensive waterworks has been disputed and its extent has never been mapped systematically

location.section: Deployment Context: The Perachora Peninsula Archaeology Project

evidence.verbatim_quote: The significance of this town—with its domestic structures and extensive waterworks—has been disputed, and its extent has never been mapped systematically

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Identical support pattern (C023). Two aspects of same research gap (disputed significance + unmapped extent) from same sentence. Assessment would evaluate together.

evidence.evidence_text: PPAP employed three methods (legacy data verification, pedestrian survey, photogrammetry); digital recording system supported first two methods

location.section: Deployment Context: The Perachora Peninsula Archaeology Project

evidence.verbatim_quote: To achieve these aims, PPAP employed three methods: 1) legacy data verification... 2) pedestrian survey... and, 3) photogrammetry... The digital recording system presented here supported the first two of these methods.

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Identical support pattern (C024). Complete method description and scope statement from adjacent sentences. Assessment would evaluate together.

evidence.evidence_text: Digital field recording systems have evolved over three decades: requirements articulated in 1990s, ARCPad systems in 2000s, iOS applications pioneered at Pompeii in early 2010s, and combinations of commercial/open-source systems proposed in last five years

location.section: System Requirements for Digital Field Data Collection

evidence.verbatim_quote: Field data collection requirements were articulated as early as the 1990s... field recording systems were developed using Esri ARCPad running on Personal Digital Assistants (PDAs)... Ellis (2016) and others working at Pompeii pioneered the use of a suite of iOS applications... Over the past five years, new field recording systems have been proposed

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Identical support pattern (C025). Sequential temporal narrative from same section. Assessment would evaluate together as single historical progression. Consolidation preserves all temporal milestones while reducing granularity.

evidence.evidence_text: A few well-funded projects built bespoke mobile solutions for particular workflows; Esri ecosystem re-emerged using ArcGIS Collector and Survey123

location.section: System Requirements for Digital Field Data Collection

evidence.verbatim_quote: A few well-funded projects or organizations have built their own bespoke mobile solutions for particular workflows... Recently, the Esri ecosystem has re-emerged as a platform for building mobile data capture systems, using ArcGIS Collector and Survey123

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Identical support pattern (C026). Two parallel approaches to current systems (bespoke + Esri) from same paragraph. Assessment would evaluate together as technology landscape.

evidence.evidence_text: PPAP needed single system capturing structured, free text, geospatial, and multimedia data
evidence.verbatim_quote: First, we demanded a single system that could capture and manage structured, free text, geospatial, and multimedia data, avoiding digitization of supplemental paper records and manual reconciliation of data collected using multiple applications.

evidence.evidence_text: PPAP had limited preparation time and short season requiring quick system deployment
evidence.verbatim_quote: Second, we needed to customize and deploy a system quickly, given limited preparation time and a short season.

evidence.evidence_text: Internet access was unavailable in field and unreliable at base
evidence.verbatim_quote: Third, internet access was unavailable in the field and unreliable at our base.

evidence.evidence_text: PPAP relied on student volunteers with little fieldwork experience, no previous work in Greece, and basic digital literacy
evidence.verbatim_quote: Like many projects, moreover, PPAP relied on student volunteers, most of whom had little fieldwork experience, had not previously worked in Greece, and had only basic digital literacy limited to the use of common consumer software.

evidence.evidence_text: Students faced combined cognitive load of adjusting to unfamiliar place, learning field methods and local materials, and confronting new technologies
evidence.verbatim_quote: The combined cognitive load was daunting; students had to adjust to an unfamiliar place, learn field methods and local materials, and confront new technologies.

evidence.evidence_text: PPAP sought to comply with FAIR data principles and TOP guidelines in the field before context was lost
evidence.verbatim_quote: We also wanted to comply with open research principles, especially the Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable (FAIR) data principles (Lindsay and Kong 2020; GO-FAIR 2017; Wilkinson et al. 2016) and the Transparency and Openness Promotion (TOP) guidelines (Nosek et al. 2015; Center for Open Science 2021)—and to do so in the field, before important context was lost.

evidence.evidence_text: Data consistency necessary for analysis can be in tension with unpredictable nature of field research because data structures are emergent and become clear only as research progresses
evidence.verbatim_quote: the data consistency necessary for analysis and reuse can be in tension with the unpredictable nature of field research... field research data structures are "emergent"—they become clear only as research progresses

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Identical support pattern (C035). Problem statement and causal explanation from same paragraph. Assessment would evaluate together as single challenge.

evidence.evidence_text: PPAP had access to project leaders' laptops, low-power industrial computer, networking gear, and Android tablets from 2015
evidence.verbatim_quote: In terms of resource constraints, we had little scope for hardware purchases or software development. In addition to project leaders' university-provided laptops, we had access to a low-power industrial computer, basic networking gear, and Android tablets, all purchased for fieldwork in 2015 (Supplemental Material 1).

evidence.evidence_text: Feature recording approach adapted from TRAP in Bulgaria (which verified over 1,000 features) included navigation to known features, recording coordinates, dimensions, photographs, drawings, and feature condition
evidence.verbatim_quote: The approach to feature recording was adapted from the Tundzha Regional Archaeology Project (TRAP) in Bulgaria, which had verified or newly mapped well over 1,000 features... During feature recording, teams navigated to known features and made a record that included coordinates, dimensions, photographs (on device and using digital cameras), drawings, and a description of the feature's condition

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Identical support pattern (C037). Precedent and workflow description from same paragraph. Assessment would evaluate together as complete methodological description.

evidence.evidence_text: Feature recording required accommodating data heterogeneity (structured data, spatial data, imagery, free-text) across wide range of anticipated features (walls, wells, cisterns, roads, staircases, caves, tombs) plus unexpected features
evidence.verbatim_quote: Accommodating data heterogeneity was the main technical challenge of feature recording. Data types included structured data (feature measurements, classification, and condition), spatial data (GPS points), imagery (photographs), and notebook-like free-text. We knew that we would encounter a wide range of features: wall or building foundations, wells, cisterns, roads, staircases, human-modified caves, and tombs. We also anticipated encountering unforeseen features.

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Identical support pattern (C038). Challenge description and scope from adjacent paragraphs. Assessment would evaluate together as complete requirement statement.

evidence.evidence_text: Expected feature dataset size: 100-300 records containing 4,900-14,700 values from 10 days fieldwork
evidence.verbatim_quote: As a result, 10 days of fieldwork would produce some 100–300 feature records containing 4,900–14,700 values.

evidence.evidence_text: PPAP adopted Mediterranean survey strategy involving teams walking contiguous areas with group recording by team
evidence.verbatim_quote: PPAP adopted a survey strategy commonly used in the Mediterranean (Bintliff and Snodgrass 1988; Davis et al. 1997; Burgers, Attema, and van Leusen 1998; Alcock and Cherry 2004; Tartaron et al. 2006; Bevan 2013), one which leveraged project leaders' experience elsewhere (Aravantinos et al. 2016; Sobotkova and Ross 2018).

evidence.evidence_text: Group recording approach enhances training and improves reliability by allowing immediate anomaly checking
evidence.verbatim_quote: We employed group recording by team, rather than individual walkers recording their own transects, to enhance training and improve the reliability of counts as survey progressed, since anomalies could be checked immediately (Burgers 1998, 45).

evidence.evidence_text: Expected survey dataset size: 200-400 records containing 117,400-234,800 values from 10 days with two teams
evidence.verbatim_quote: Each team would complete 10–20 units (potentially 5,870–11,740 values) per day; across 10 days of fieldwork, two teams would thus produce some 200–400 records containing 117,400–234,800 values.

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS Project has been developing field data capture systems since 2012, informed by stocktaking among Australian and international archaeological community
evidence.verbatim_quote: Informed by stocktaking among the Australian and international archaeological community, the FAIMS Project has been developing field data capture systems since 2012 (Sobotkova et al. 2016; Ross et al. 2013).

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS Mobile incorporates highly abstracted domain-key normal-form (DKNF) database recording entities, attributes, and values
evidence.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile can accommodate a wide range of field research because it incorporates a highly abstracted domain-key normal-form (DKNF) database that records entities, attributes, and values.

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS datastore is append-only (deletes/edits create new version), intrinsically maintaining value history
evidence.verbatim_quote: The FAIMS datastore is append-only (deletes or edits create a new version of the record), intrinsically maintaining a history of each value's creation, modification, and deletion.

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS Mobile was customized for cataloguing burial mounds in Bulgaria in 2017 and used during two field seasons 2017-2018, optimized for navigating to features and capturing dimensions, location, and condition
evidence.verbatim_quote: In 2017, FAIMS Mobile was customized for cataloguing burial mounds and other features known from historical maps in Bulgaria. It was used during two field seasons in 2017–2018. The module was optimized for navigating to and capturing the dimensions, location, environmental setting, and condition of burial mounds.

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Identical support pattern (C046). Complete precedent description from same paragraph.

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS provides default export formats (CSV, shapefile, KML) with customization possible
evidence.verbatim_quote: Data export can also be customized: tabular (CSV), shapefile, and KML export are provided by default, with other export formats possible (e.g., for ingesting into a repository or relational database).

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS includes automated load testing to predict field performance
evidence.verbatim_quote: FAIMS therefore incorporates automated load testing to predict field performance (see "Results" below and Supplemental Material 4).

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS customization requires no predefined data structure or UI; users define from scratch or adapt existing
evidence.verbatim_quote: Unlike other systems such as iDAI.field (Deutsches Archäologisches Institut 2021) or iDig (Blackwell 2016; Uildriks 2016), users do not extend a predefined data structure or UI. Since no "defaults" exist, FAIMS Mobile must be customized before use.

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS customization called a 'module' is defined by XML files, not programming
evidence.verbatim_quote: FAIMS is not really a "bespoke [system] incorporating databases … often custom built by programming specialists" (contra Lindsay and Kong 2020, 322–323), however, or a group of "multiple applications," each built for a specific task (contra Cobb et al. 2019, 140). Instead, it is a single, "generalized" platform that produces custom applications from XML definition files.

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS has been customized for over 60 workflows on more than 40 projects across multiple disciplines
evidence.verbatim_quote: Although FAIMS Mobile was initially designed for archaeology, this flexibility has allowed it to be customized for over 60 workflows on more than 40 projects in geoscience, ecology, ethnography, linguistics, oral history, and other domains (Thorne et al. 2018; Noble et al. 2019).

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS provides unique identifiers (20-digit based on user and time) plus human-readable identifiers that can be constructed from text, numbers, or record values
evidence.verbatim_quote: FAIMS provides each record with a 20-digit unique identifier (based on user and time). Each entity also allows the specification of "human-readable" identifiers during module creation. These identifiers can be constructed in a variety of ways, including from text, numbers, or values contained in the record.

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Identical support pattern (C052). Two complementary identifier types from same paragraph.

evidence.evidence_text: Two pre-existing FAIMS modules were reused for PPAP: Feature Recording (used twice in Bulgaria) and prototype Gridded Survey
evidence.verbatim_quote: Two pre-existing FAIMS modules were reused for PPAP: a Feature Recording module used twice in Bulgaria and a prototype surface survey module built to explore the field-recording challenges inherent to this activity.

evidence.evidence_text: Feature Recording module adaptation took approximately 53 person-hours over five days
evidence.verbatim_quote: Adaptation of the existing module took approximately 53 person-hours over five days, after which we had a customization suitable for recording a range of legacy features (Nassif-Haynes et al. 2020b).

evidence.evidence_text: Gridded Survey module was deployed by PPAP without modification in same five-day timeframe as Feature Recording
evidence.verbatim_quote: This "Gridded Survey" module had not previously been used in the field. It was deployed by PPAP without modification in the same five-day timeframe as Feature Recording (Nassif-Haynes et al. 2020a).

evidence.evidence_text: PPAP used FAIMS Mobile for almost 135 hours during two weeks, recording 285 survey units in 10 days and 108 features in 11 days, capturing ~167,295 values in survey units and ~5,292 values in features
evidence.verbatim_quote: PPAP participants used FAIMS Mobile for a total of almost 135 hours during two weeks of fieldwork from 14–29 January. We recorded 285 survey units in 10 days and 108 features in 11 days... Since a typical survey unit record contained 587 values, about 167,295 discrete values were recorded in total. The time required to record a feature varied, but averaged about one hour. Feature records contained 49 values each, thus yielding another 5,292 values.

consolidation_metadata.granularity_available: Original items separated usage hours, record counts, and value counts
consolidation_metadata.rationale: Identical support pattern (C056). Multiple measurements of same deployment outcome from same location. Assessment would evaluate together as single performance finding. All key metrics preserved in consolidated form.

evidence.evidence_text: Average survey velocity was 4.8 units per hour
evidence.verbatim_quote: The average survey velocity was 4.8 units per hour.

evidence.evidence_text: Gridded Survey module performance degraded and one device became unstable around 230 survey units (>135,000 values)
evidence.verbatim_quote: The assumptions built into the tests were too pessimistic, however, and we were able to collect around 230 survey unit records (> 135,000 values) before one device became unstable. This malfunction required a restart, but no data were lost.

evidence.evidence_text: Automated testing suggested Gridded Survey performance would degrade between 50-200 units, but 230 units were collected before one device became unstable; device successfully synchronized and was replaced seamlessly
evidence.verbatim_quote: Automated testing of the Gridded Survey module suggested that performance would degrade between 50 and 200 units... we were able to collect around 230 survey unit records (> 135,000 values) before one device became unstable. This malfunction required a restart, but no data were lost. The device was used for the remainder of the day but continued to perform poorly. Data successfully synchronized in the evening. The remaining 55 survey units were recorded using other tablets, as bi-directional synchronization allowed seamless replacement of any device at any time.

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Identical support pattern (C059). Problem and recovery from same paragraph.

evidence.evidence_text: Consolidated datasets were exported daily for review in spreadsheet and GIS software, used to inform decision-making including artifact pickup locations and diagnostic inventorying
evidence.verbatim_quote: Consolidated datasets were exported daily for review in desktop spreadsheet and GIS software. These data were used to inform decision-making. Total artifact pickups, for example, began the day after the survey finished, with locations chosen on the basis of artifact count heat maps. Diagnostic artifacts were inventoried during the last week of survey

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Identical support pattern (C060). Data availability and use examples from same paragraph.

evidence.evidence_text: Compared to hybrid paper-digital TRAP approach, fully digital FAIMS workflow saved 2-3 hours daily on digitization, 1 hour on synchronization, half day weekly on validation, plus time on data history tracking and processing
evidence.verbatim_quote: Compared to that approach, we estimate that the fully digital workflow using FAIMS Mobile offered the following time savings: 1) a more comprehensive system saved all team members 2–3 hours of paper form digitization and manual image labelling and renaming each day; 2) automated synchronization saved team leaders about 1 hour of tending the manual aspects of ArcPad data synchronization each day; 3) data validation saved team leaders 1/2 day per week previously spent checking and correcting errors...

evidence.evidence_text: Project participants experienced less anxiety and fewer emergency after-hours work bouts due to elimination of manual process failures
evidence.verbatim_quote: Qualitatively, project participants also experienced less anxiety and fewer bouts of emergency after-hours work, since failures of digitization, data transfer, backups, and other manual or semi-automated processes were eliminated.

evidence.evidence_text: PPAP did not aim for efficiency at expense of all else; free-text options provided to mimic margins of page
evidence.verbatim_quote: PPAP did not, however, aim to achieve efficiency at the expense of all else. Instead, we sought unobtrusive systems that could produce consistent, born-digital data. While controlled vocabularies, picture dictionaries, and automation were used to standardize data and streamline repetitive tasks, free-text entry options were provided to mimic the "margins of the page."

The ability to adapt and reuse two existing customizations available in the FAIMS module library allowed us to deploy comprehensive digital systems for archaeological survey and legacy feature verification in less than a week.
evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS Mobile customization for two workflows was deployed in less than one week

System performance across three weeks of fast-paced fieldwork was satisfactory with recording speed comparable to paper, but data were better described, more consistent, and did not require later digitization or extensive cleaning
evidence.verbatim_quote: Performance across three weeks of fast-paced and changing fieldwork was satisfactory—speed was comparable to paper, but data were better described, more consistent, and did not require later digitization or extensive cleaning.

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Identical support pattern (C068, C069). Single comparative statement from same sentence.

evidence.evidence_text: Well-described dataset of nearly 400 records containing over 170,000 discrete values was ready for analysis with a few hours of additional processing after fieldwork ended
evidence.verbatim_quote: A well-described dataset of nearly 400 records containing over 170,000 discrete values was ready for analysis with a few hours of additional processing after fieldwork ended

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Identical support pattern (C070, C071). Dataset scale and readiness from same sentence.

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile deployment at PPAP was used to document two field workflows (systematic pedestrian survey and legacy feature verification)
claims.verbatim_quote: This article discusses the deployment of mobile data capture software developed by the Field Acquired Information Management Systems project (FAIMS Mobile) to document systematic pedestrian surface survey and legacy feature verification at the Perachora Peninsula Archaeology Project (PPAP), Greece, in 2020.

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile was tailored to PPAP's aims and methods through reuse and adaptation of existing customizations
claims.verbatim_quote: It was tailored to our aims and methods, captured consistent and well-described data rapidly, and minimized post-processing.

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile integrated multiple data types (structured data, geospatial data, photos, and text) in a single system
claims.verbatim_quote: We reused and adapted two existing customizations from the FAIMS library for comprehensive digital recording of two workflows, integrating a collection of structured data, geospatial data, photos, and text.

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile has modest hardware requirements
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile required only modest hardware but supported offline setup, synchronization, and data export, allowing PPAP to deploy it despite unreliable internet access.

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile's offline capabilities allowed PPAP to deploy it despite unreliable internet access
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile required only modest hardware but supported offline setup, synchronization, and data export, allowing PPAP to deploy it despite unreliable internet access.

claims.claim_text: The FAIMS Mobile system proved successful
claims.verbatim_quote: The system proved successful; it was tailored to our aims and methods, captured consistent and well-described data rapidly, and minimized post-processing.

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile enabled daily data availability for planning during fieldwork
claims.verbatim_quote: All collected data was available daily for planning, and a comprehensive dataset adhering to Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable (FAIR) data standards was ready for analysis with only a few hours of processing after fieldwork.

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile produced a FAIR-compliant dataset ready for analysis with minimal post-fieldwork processing
claims.verbatim_quote: All collected data was available daily for planning, and a comprehensive dataset adhering to Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable (FAIR) data standards was ready for analysis with only a few hours of processing after fieldwork.

claims.verbatim_quote: In such an environment, archaeologists often organize information idiosyncratically, using an ad-hoc mix of paper, digital data fragments from various applications, and bespoke databases (Kintigh 2006; Snow et al. 2006; Kansa and Bissell 2010; Rabinowitz 2016; Sobotkova and Hermankova forthcoming).

claims.claim_text: Non-integrated data recording approaches demand time-consuming reconciliation and cleaning

claims.verbatim_quote: Even where datasets exist, they are often poorly documented and difficult to reuse.

claims.verbatim_quote: These deficiencies not only undermine research integrity, but also inhibit independent analyses of primary data, the application of new techniques to old datasets, and the synthesis of data from multiple studies to address disciplinary grand challenges (Kintigh 2006, 567; Kintigh et al. 2014; McNutt et al. 2016).
