claims.claim_text: Field data collection challenges lead to a digital bottleneck that impedes later analysis and publication

location.section: The Challenge of Digital Field Data Collection

claims.verbatim_quote: Together, these challenges lead to a digital bottleneck during fieldwork that impedes the later analysis and publication of data.

claims.claim_text: PPAP is structured as a three-year joint Greek-Australian project with institutional backing and governmental permits

location.section: Deployment Context: The Perachora Peninsula Archaeology Project

claims.verbatim_quote: PPAP is a three-year synergasia (a joint Greek-Australian project) co-directed by Panagiota Kasimi (Director of the Ephorate of Antiquities of the Corinthia) and Susan Lupack (Macquarie University) under the aegis of the Australian Archaeological Institute at Athens.

claims.claim_text: PPAP is diachronic in nature, addressing sites from Early Helladic through Byzantine eras

location.section: Deployment Context: The Perachora Peninsula Archaeology Project

claims.verbatim_quote: As such, PPAP is diachronic in nature, and initial research goals included the production of: 1) an inventory of the remains of habitation, funerary, and hydraulic structures discovered in the past but not recorded to current standards, 2) intensive survey of known features or sites to map the extent of activity areas as they evolved over time, and 3) survey of unexplored areas of the peninsula in order to acquire a fuller understanding of settlement patterns.

claims.claim_text: 2020 season was exploratory, aimed to provide initial data for refining research questions and evaluating field conditions and methods

location.section: Deployment Context: The Perachora Peninsula Archaeology Project

claims.verbatim_quote: The 2020 season was exploratory in nature and limited to three weeks. It aimed to provide initial data allowing refinement of the broad goals of the project into more specific research questions and hypotheses, as well as to evaluate field conditions and assess fieldwork methods and associated recording technologies.

claims.claim_text: 2020 season time constraint (three weeks) influenced technology evaluation priorities

location.section: Deployment Context: The Perachora Peninsula Archaeology Project

claims.verbatim_quote: The 2020 season was exploratory in nature and limited to three weeks.

claims.claim_text: Mapping surface artifact distributions addresses gaps in previous research that disputed town significance and never systematically mapped extent

location.section: Deployment Context: The Perachora Peninsula Archaeology Project

claims.verbatim_quote: We sought to map surface artifact distributions to contextualize the standing features that were the focus of previous work.

claims.claim_text: PPAP employed three methods with digital recording supporting two of them (legacy data verification and pedestrian survey)

location.section: Deployment Context: The Perachora Peninsula Archaeology Project

claims.verbatim_quote: To achieve these aims, PPAP employed three methods: 1) legacy data verification, involving accurate documentation of features noted during previous fieldwork (and recording of unknown features found in the process); 2) pedestrian survey mapping the distribution of surface artifacts and features; and, 3) photogrammetry of significant features. The digital recording system presented here supported the first two of these methods.

claims.claim_text: Field data collection requirements and solutions have evolved over three decades from 1990s to present

location.section: System Requirements for Digital Field Data Collection

claims.verbatim_quote: Field data collection requirements were articulated as early as the 1990s, underscoring the challenge of creating context-aware applications to support field walkers in data recording and validation (Pascoe, Ryan, and Morse 1998; Ryan, Pascoe, and Morse 1999).

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile offers an alternative to commercial and bespoke field recording solutions

location.section: System Requirements for Digital Field Data Collection

claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile offers an alternative: an open-source platform designed specifically for field research that can be customized like a bespoke system but more quickly and at a lower cost.

claims.claim_text: No software offers a perfect solution to every field scenario; projects must prioritize requirements and assess tradeoffs

location.section: System Requirements for Digital Field Data Collection

claims.verbatim_quote: No software offers a perfect solution to every field scenario. Each project must prioritize requirements, assess challenges, and consider tradeoffs between different digital toolkits.

claims.claim_text: Any recording system for mobile fieldwork must meet long-established common requirements from 1990s

location.section: System Requirements for Digital Field Data Collection

claims.verbatim_quote: Nevertheless, any recording system for mobile fieldwork has to meet long-established requirements (Pascoe, Ryan, and Morse 1998; Ryan, Pascoe, and Morse 1999; Wagtendonk and De Jue 2007)

claims.claim_text: PPAP required single system managing multiple data types to avoid supplemental paper digitization and manual reconciliation
claims.verbatim_quote: First, we demanded a single system that could capture and manage structured, free text, geospatial, and multimedia data, avoiding digitization of supplemental paper records and manual reconciliation of data collected using multiple applications.

claims.claim_text: Limited preparation time and short season required quick system customization and deployment
claims.verbatim_quote: Second, we needed to customize and deploy a system quickly, given limited preparation time and a short season.

claims.claim_text: System needed to operate entirely offline for data collection and all administrative tasks (setup, synchronization, export)
claims.verbatim_quote: Not only did devices need to collect data entirely offline, but system setup and modification, as well as data management, review, synchronization, and export, had to be accomplished without recourse to the internet.

claims.claim_text: System needed to ensure data quality and consistency through controlled vocabularies, data entry constraints, and validation
claims.verbatim_quote: As such, we needed to ensure the quality and consistency of data, which required unrelenting use of controlled vocabularies, other data entry constraints, and data validation.

claims.claim_text: Digital recording system had to be easy to use, guide informed observation, and avoid de-skilling while supporting student training
claims.verbatim_quote: Any digital recording system had to be easy to use and contribute to student learning. In particular, we sought a system that would guide rather than supplant informed observation, thereby avoiding the disengaged recording and "de-skilling" observed by critics of efficiency-focused digital approaches (e.g., Caraher 2016).

claims.claim_text: PPAP aimed to apply FAIR and TOP principles during field data collection before context was lost
claims.verbatim_quote: We also wanted to comply with open research principles, especially the Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable (FAIR) data principles (Lindsay and Kong 2020; GO-FAIR 2017; Wilkinson et al. 2016) and the Transparency and Openness Promotion (TOP) guidelines (Nosek et al. 2015; Center for Open Science 2021)—and to do so in the field, before important context was lost.

claims.claim_text: System needed to balance serendipity of fieldwork against need for data consistency, especially for first season field-testing methods
claims.verbatim_quote: We looked for a system that could balance the serendipity of fieldwork against the need for consistency, especially since PPAP was undertaking its first season and needed to field-test and adjust methods, systems, data structures, and workflows.

claims.claim_text: PPAP sought to avoid expensive proprietary software while recognizing bespoke development was beyond capacity
claims.verbatim_quote: As such, we sought to avoid the use of expensive proprietary software, while recognizing that bespoke development or time-consuming customization was beyond our capacity.

claims.claim_text: Feature recording methodology was successfully adapted from TRAP project which had verified over 1,000 features
claims.verbatim_quote: The approach to feature recording was adapted from the Tundzha Regional Archaeology Project (TRAP) in Bulgaria, which had verified or newly mapped well over 1,000 features, mostly burial mounds (Sobotkova and Ross 2018; Valchev and Sobotkova 2019; Sobotkova and Weissova 2020).

claims.claim_text: Feature recording posed small data problems of data variety and inability to pre-specify comprehensive data model
claims.verbatim_quote: Feature verification thus posed the well-known "small data" problems of data variety and an inability to pre-specify a comprehensive data model (Kansa and Bissell 2010; Borgman 2015).

claims.claim_text: Feature recording data volume was not expected to be large enough to pose offline database performance problems
claims.verbatim_quote: The feature dataset, however, was not expected to be large enough to pose problems.

claims.claim_text: PPAP adopted team-based Mediterranean survey strategy leveraging project leaders' experience
claims.verbatim_quote: PPAP adopted a survey strategy commonly used in the Mediterranean (Bintliff and Snodgrass 1988; Davis et al. 1997; Burgers, Attema, and van Leusen 1998; Alcock and Cherry 2004; Tartaron et al. 2006; Bevan 2013), one which leveraged project leaders' experience elsewhere (Aravantinos et al. 2016; Sobotkova and Ross 2018).

claims.claim_text: Group recording approach was chosen to enhance training and improve reliability through immediate anomaly checking
claims.verbatim_quote: We employed group recording by team, rather than individual walkers recording their own transects, to enhance training and improve the reliability of counts as survey progressed, since anomalies could be checked immediately (Burgers 1998, 45).

claims.claim_text: Survey data volume and required recording pace posed significant technical challenges for digital systems
claims.verbatim_quote: Although survey data were less diverse than feature recording, the volume of data posed a technical challenge. It placed greater demands on devices and required a well-conceived user interface (UI) to accommodate the pace of recording and organization of the data.

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile is open-source platform for generating customized Android applications for field research data capture
claims.verbatim_quote: The project's principal output is FAIMS Mobile, an open-source platform that generates customized mobile applications for human-mediated observations during fieldwork of all kinds (Ross et al. 2015; Sobotkova et al. 2015, 2016; Ballsun-Stanton et al. 2018; VanValkenburgh et al. 2018; Noble et al. 2019).

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile's abstracted DKNF database architecture enables accommodation of wide range of field research workflows
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile can accommodate a wide range of field research because it incorporates a highly abstracted domain-key normal-form (DKNF) database that records entities, attributes, and values.

claims.claim_text: FAIMS append-only datastore architecture intrinsically maintains complete data history and provenance
claims.verbatim_quote: The FAIMS datastore is append-only (deletes or edits create a new version of the record), intrinsically maintaining a history of each value's creation, modification, and deletion.

claims.claim_text: FAIMS automatic bi-directional synchronization ensures all devices have complete, up-to-date dataset
claims.verbatim_quote: Opportunistic, incremental, bi-directional synchronization is automatic.

claims.claim_text: FAIMS data export can be customized for different formats and repositories
claims.verbatim_quote: Data export can also be customized: tabular (CSV), shapefile, and KML export are provided by default, with other export formats possible (e.g., for ingesting into a repository or relational database).

claims.claim_text: FAIMS approach trades speed for flexibility and versioning, requiring automated load testing to predict performance
claims.verbatim_quote: The FAIMS approach to data storage provides flexibility and versioning at the expense of speed as the number of records increases. FAIMS therefore incorporates automated load testing to predict field performance

claims.claim_text: Unlike systems with predefined structures, FAIMS requires customization but offers complete flexibility in data model and UI design
claims.verbatim_quote: Unlike other systems such as iDAI.field (Deutsches Archäologisches Institut 2021) or iDig (Blackwell 2016; Uildriks 2016), users do not extend a predefined data structure or UI. Since no "defaults" exist, FAIMS Mobile must be customized before use.

claims.claim_text: FAIMS is generalized platform producing custom applications from XML definition files, not bespoke programming
claims.verbatim_quote: Instead, it is a single, "generalized" platform that produces custom applications from XML definition files.

claims.claim_text: FAIMS flexibility has enabled customization for over 60 workflows across multiple disciplines beyond archaeology
claims.verbatim_quote: Although FAIMS Mobile was initially designed for archaeology, this flexibility has allowed it to be customized for over 60 workflows on more than 40 projects in geoscience, ecology, ethnography, linguistics, oral history, and other domains (Thorne et al. 2018; Noble et al. 2019).

claims.claim_text: FAIMS module creation is faster and less costly than bespoke development while maintaining customization flexibility
claims.verbatim_quote: Use of definition files like these permits much faster and less costly production of customized recording systems compared to bespoke software development

claims.claim_text: PPAP reused and adapted two existing FAIMS modules from open library for its two workflows
claims.verbatim_quote: Two pre-existing FAIMS modules were reused for PPAP: a Feature Recording module used twice in Bulgaria and a prototype surface survey module built to explore the field-recording challenges inherent to this activity.

claims.claim_text: Feature Recording module was successfully adapted for PPAP in 53 person-hours over five days
claims.verbatim_quote: Adaptation of the existing module took approximately 53 person-hours over five days, after which we had a customization suitable for recording a range of legacy features (Nassif-Haynes et al. 2020b).

claims.claim_text: Gridded Survey module was deployed without modification within same five-day timeframe as Feature Recording adaptation
claims.verbatim_quote: This "Gridded Survey" module had not previously been used in the field. It was deployed by PPAP without modification in the same five-day timeframe as Feature Recording (Nassif-Haynes et al. 2020a).

claims.claim_text: PPAP successfully collected substantial dataset (285 survey units, 108 features, >172,000 values) using FAIMS Mobile over two weeks
claims.verbatim_quote: After one week of project setup and initial training, PPAP participants used FAIMS Mobile for a total of almost 135 hours during two weeks of fieldwork from 14–29 January. We recorded 285 survey units in 10 days and 108 features in 11 days (Figure 11).

claims.claim_text: Survey recording pace (4.8 units/hour) was comparable to paper recording
claims.verbatim_quote: The average survey velocity was 4.8 units per hour.

claims.claim_text: System performance was satisfactory with only one device malfunction (at ~230 units) that required restart but caused no data loss
claims.verbatim_quote: The assumptions built into the tests were too pessimistic, however, and we were able to collect around 230 survey unit records (> 135,000 values) before one device became unstable. This malfunction required a restart, but no data were lost.

claims.claim_text: System performance met PPAP requirements with satisfactory operation and device replaceability
claims.verbatim_quote: Feature Recording module performance was satisfactory throughout fieldwork.

claims.claim_text: FAIMS enabled daily data availability for decision-making and rapid post-fieldwork dataset preparation
claims.verbatim_quote: Consolidated datasets were exported daily for review in desktop spreadsheet and GIS software. These data were used to inform decision-making. ... Analysis- and publication-ready datasets were available less than two weeks after fieldwork.

claims.claim_text: Fully digital FAIMS workflow provided significant time savings compared to hybrid paper-digital approach across multiple workflow stages
claims.verbatim_quote: Compared to that approach, we estimate that the fully digital workflow using FAIMS Mobile offered the following time savings...

claims.claim_text: Digital workflow reduced project participant anxiety and emergency work by eliminating manual process failures
claims.verbatim_quote: Qualitatively, project participants also experienced less anxiety and fewer bouts of emergency after-hours work, since failures of digitization, data transfer, backups, and other manual or semi-automated processes were eliminated.

claims.claim_text: PPAP sought unobtrusive systems producing consistent data while preserving researcher flexibility through free-text options
claims.verbatim_quote: PPAP did not, however, aim to achieve efficiency at the expense of all else. Instead, we sought unobtrusive systems that could produce consistent, born-digital data.

claims.claim_text: Time freed from data management was used to expand student training rather than just increase efficiency
claims.verbatim_quote: In short, reducing data digitization and correction saved time, while the ability to reassemble disparate field data (Caraher 2016) through synchronization, export, and visualization provided high-quality, timely information—a combination that fostered reflection on the archaeological record as it emerged and refinement of fieldwork informed by data.

claims.claim_text: Research-specific software like FAIMS avoids constraints imposed by mass-market products not designed for archaeological research
claims.verbatim_quote: Although the small market represented by archaeology complicates the economics of specialized software, it also ensures that most mass-market products (commercial or open-source) are not designed for archaeological research. This mismatch imposes undue constraints on field researchers.

claims.claim_text: Ability to capture different data types in single application and operate entirely offline were essential features not routinely available in mass-market products
claims.verbatim_quote: Two such features were essential to PPAP: the ability to capture different types of data in the same application and the capacity of the entire system to operate offline.

claims.claim_text: FAIMS built-in approach to FAIR data applied during collection stage offers advantages over bolt-on approaches applied after processing

location.section: Discussion - FAIR data in the field

claims.verbatim_quote: Open-research approaches are often "bolt-on," considered only after data are collected and processed. FAIMS Mobile, however, offered a "built-in" solution, applied during the collection stage of the data lifecycle.
FAIMS Mobile was the best match for these conditions and requirements.
claims.alternatives_considered: Other digital recording systems mentioned in Discussion section
claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile was the best match for PPAP's field conditions and requirements
claims.claim_nature: Evaluation claim based on requirements matching

claims.verbatim_quote: Aggressive use of controlled vocabularies, automation, validation, and in-application help augmented training and improved the quality of data generated largely by student volunteers.
claims.claim_text: Controlled vocabularies, automation, validation, and in-application help improved data quality from student volunteers
claims.claim_nature: Attribution of data quality to system features

claims.verbatim_quote: Combined datasets from both activities were available daily for planning. A well-described dataset of nearly 400 records containing over 170,000 discrete values was ready for analysis with a few hours of additional processing after fieldwork ended
claims.claim_text: Combined dataset was well-described and analysis-ready with minimal post-processing
claims.claim_nature: Assessment of dataset quality and readiness

claims.verbatim_quote: Overall, the two FAIMS modules used by PPAP supported our own research goals while realizing much of the potential of digital field recording to improve the discoverability, transparency, and reusability of archaeological data.
claims.disciplinary_context: Open research archaeology, FAIR data principles
claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile modules supported PPAP research goals while realizing digital field recording potential for data discoverability, transparency, and reusability
claims.claim_nature: Overarching evaluation claim integrating research and open science benefits

claims.verbatim_quote: future fieldwork will add to this dataset with little additional technological effort
expected_information_missing: Specific description of what technological effort would be required
claims.claim_text: Future PPAP fieldwork will add to the dataset with little additional technological effort

claims.verbatim_quote: Submission of the dataset to a repository will be straightforward.
claims.claim_text: Submission of PPAP dataset to a repository will be straightforward

implicit_arguments.implicit_text: Success of a digital field recording system can be evaluated based on tailoring, data consistency, capture speed, minimal post-processing, daily availability, and FAIR compliance
trigger_text: The system proved successful; it was tailored to our aims and methods, captured consistent and well-described data rapidly, and minimized post-processing.

All collected data was available daily for planning, and a comprehensive dataset adhering to Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable (FAIR) data standards was ready for analysis with only a few hours of processing after fieldwork.
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Authors assert system 'proved successful' and immediately follow with list of characteristics (tailored, consistent, rapid, minimal post-processing, daily availability, FAIR compliance). This structure implies these characteristics constitute the criteria for 'success,' but authors never explicitly state 'success means X' or 'we evaluate success by...' The criteria are implied through juxtaposition and used throughout paper to structure evaluation.

implicit_arguments.implicit_text: 'Modest hardware' is adequate for field research if it supports required functionality (offline operation, synchronization, data export)
trigger_text: FAIMS Mobile required only modest hardware but supported offline setup, synchronization, and data export, allowing PPAP to deploy it despite unreliable internet access.
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Authors present 'modest hardware' and 'supported offline setup' with contrastive 'but,' implying functional capability matters more than hardware specifications. However, they never explicitly state threshold for 'adequate' hardware or criteria for evaluating hardware requirements. The implicit assumption is that functionality (offline, sync, export) is the relevant adequacy criterion, not hardware specifications. This allows 'modest' to be positioned positively.

implicit_arguments.implicit_text: FAIR data standards are achievable during field data collection rather than only through post-fieldwork processing
trigger_text: All collected data was available daily for planning, and a comprehensive dataset adhering to Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable (FAIR) data standards was ready for analysis with only a few hours of processing after fieldwork.
Critical data and metadata must be captured in the field or risk being lost (Buck 2015; McNutt et al. 2016; Digital Curation Centre 2020).

trigger_locations.section: The Challenge of Digital Field Data Collection

implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Authors claim FAIR dataset was 'ready for analysis with only a few hours of processing after fieldwork' and emphasize that 'critical data and metadata must be captured in the field.' This positioning implies FAIR compliance can and should be achieved during collection, not solely through post-hoc processing. However, they never explicitly state that FAIR is achievable in-field or contrast field-time FAIR with post-hoc FAIR. The argument depends on this possibility being true (otherwise their achievement would not be notable), but it's never defended or acknowledged as a design assumption.

implicit_arguments.implicit_text: Existing approaches to archaeological field data collection create 'significant compromises' that are problematic enough to motivate alternative solutions
trigger_text: Mass-market software designed primarily for other purposes is often a poor fit for such requirements, demanding that researchers make significant compromises.
Together, these challenges lead to a digital bottleneck during fieldwork that impedes the later analysis and publication of data.
This paper presents the deployment of a research-specific, comprehensive, offline-first digital recording system designed to address these challenges

trigger_locations.section: The Challenge of Digital Field Data Collection
The Challenge of Digital Field Data Collection
The Challenge of Digital Field Data Collection

implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Authors state mass-market software demands 'significant compromises' and creates 'digital bottleneck,' then immediately present FAIMS as solution 'designed to address these challenges.' This rhetorical structure positions existing compromises as problematic enough to justify new approach. However, authors never explicitly state 'these compromises are unacceptable' or 'bottleneck severity justifies alternative approach.' The bridging claim that existing compromises are problematically severe (rather than acceptable tradeoffs) is implied by problem-solution framing but never defended.

location.section: The Challenge of Digital Field Data Collection

implicit_arguments.implicit_text: Comparable recording pace to paper is evidence of system success and usability
trigger_text: The average survey velocity was 4.8 units per hour.
The system proved successful; it was tailored to our aims and methods, captured consistent and well-described data rapidly, and minimized post-processing.
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Authors present survey velocity metric (4.8 units/hour) as evidence supporting system success claim. However, they never explicitly state what velocity would be acceptable, what paper recording pace is, or why comparable pace matters. The implicit assumption is that maintaining paper-equivalent speed while gaining digital benefits demonstrates successful system design. This evaluative criterion is implied through metric presentation but never explicitly defended or acknowledged.

trigger_text: The ability to adapt and reuse two existing customizations available in the FAIMS module library allowed us to deploy comprehensive digital systems for archaeological survey and legacy feature verification in less than a week.
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The emphasis on rapid deployment ('less than a week') implies comparison to longer deployment times for other systems. The claim's significance depends on the unstated assumption that week-scale deployment represents a practical advantage over alternatives requiring longer setup.
implicit_arguments.implicit_text: If FAIMS Mobile deployment time is measured in days rather than weeks/months, then it represents a practical solution for time-constrained projects

research_designs.design_text: Comparative case study design to evaluate FAIMS Mobile platform against common requirements for field data recording and open research principles
research_designs.verbatim_quote: This paper presents the deployment of a research-specific, comprehensive, offline-first digital recording system designed to address these challenges during the initial 2020 season of the Perachora Peninsula Archaeological Project (PPAP).
research_designs.design_rationale: To demonstrate how research-specific software can address archaeological field data collection challenges while supporting FAIR principles
expected_information_missing: Explicit statement of comparative evaluation as research design
Selection criteria for case study site

research_designs.design_text: Requirements-driven system deployment design where field data collection requirements are articulated and matched against system capabilities

location.section: System Requirements for Digital Field Data Collection

research_designs.verbatim_quote: Field data collection requirements were articulated as early as the 1990s, underscoring the challenge of creating context-aware applications to support field walkers in data recording and validation (Pascoe, Ryan, and Morse 1998; Ryan, Pascoe, and Morse 1999).
research_designs.design_rationale: To ensure system selection and customization address actual field research needs

methods.method_text: Reuse and adaptation of existing software modules from open library to create customized field recording applications
methods.verbatim_quote: We reused and adapted two existing customizations from the FAIMS library for comprehensive digital recording of two workflows, integrating a collection of structured data, geospatial data, photos, and text.
methods.method_purpose: To quickly deploy field-ready recording systems tailored to project workflows

methods.method_text: Parallel deployment of two distinct field recording workflows: legacy feature verification and pedestrian survey
methods.verbatim_quote: To achieve these aims, PPAP employed three methods: 1) legacy data verification, involving accurate documentation of features noted during previous fieldwork (and recording of unknown features found in the process); 2) pedestrian survey mapping the distribution of surface artifacts and features; and, 3) photogrammetry of significant features. The digital recording system presented here supported the first two of these methods.
methods.method_purpose: To document both legacy features and surface artifact distributions in study area

methods.method_text: Offline-first data management using local server for module instantiation, synchronization, and export
methods.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile required only modest hardware but supported offline setup, synchronization, and data export, allowing PPAP to deploy it despite unreliable internet access.
methods.method_purpose: To enable data collection and management without reliable internet connectivity

methods.method_text: XML-based module customization using definition files to specify data structure, user interface, and validation rules
methods.verbatim_quote: Users do not extend a predefined data structure or UI. Since no "defaults" exist, FAIMS Mobile must be customized before use. To do so, users define their own data structure and digital forms from scratch or adapt an existing customization. Such a customization is called a "module." ... Depending on the level of control needed, separate definition files can be used to instantiate data structure, UI, and validation rules, or all three can be generated from one, simplified XML file
methods.method_purpose: To create field-ready applications tailored to specific research workflows

methods.method_text: Data quality assurance through aggressive use of controlled vocabularies, automation of value inheritance and derivation, and on-device validation
methods.verbatim_quote: Aggressive use of controlled vocabularies, automation, validation, and in-application help augmented training and improved the quality of data generated largely by student volunteers.
methods.method_purpose: To ensure data consistency and quality despite use of inexperienced student volunteers

methods.method_text: Daily review of exported data in GIS and spreadsheet software to inform next-day planning and detect errors while memories fresh
methods.verbatim_quote: Once server-side validation was completed, data and multimedia were exported from the FAIMS server and stored on a separate file server, where they were accessible to project participants.
methods.method_purpose: To enable rapid error detection and responsive fieldwork planning

methods.method_text: Student volunteer training method: train inexperienced students in field methods, local materials, and digital recording systems
trigger_text: Like many projects, moreover, PPAP relied on student volunteers, most of whom had little fieldwork experience, had not previously worked in Greece, and had only basic digital literacy limited to the use of common consumer software.
Teams of five were trained to walk spaced 5 m apart in a 25 × 25 m grid, called a "survey unit."
One of the main aims of PPAP was to train students.
methods.inference_reasoning: The paper repeatedly mentions student training as a project component and emphasizes reliance on inexperienced student volunteers, but never documents the training method. Triggers show: (1) students had little fieldwork experience, (2) students lacked local knowledge, (3) students had basic digital literacy only, (4) training in survey methods occurred ("teams trained to walk"), (5) training students was a main project aim. This implies a systematic training method including curriculum, duration, assessment, and skill development, but training procedures are not documented in Methods.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: Training method not documented: training curriculum, duration, instructional approach, assessment of student competency, practice exercises, error detection and correction during training
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Cannot assess whether student training was adequate to ensure data quality and consistency, or evaluate training effectiveness

methods.method_purpose: To enable inexperienced students to collect reliable archaeological field data using digital systems

methods.method_text: Retrospective efficiency comparison method: compare time spent on field data management between current FAIMS-based workflow and previous hybrid paper-digital workflow
trigger_text: Three of the authors conducted TRAP fieldwork in Bulgaria from 2008–2011 using hybrid paper and digital (ArcPad-based) field data recording (Ross et al. 2010; Sobotkova and Ross 2018). Compared to that approach, we estimate that the fully digital workflow using FAIMS Mobile offered the following time savings: 1) a more comprehensive system saved all team members 2–3 hours of paper form digitization and manual image labelling and renaming each day; 2) automated synchronization saved team leaders about 1 hour of tending the manual aspects of ArcPad data synchronization each day; 3) data validation saved team leaders 1/2 day per week previously spent checking and correcting errors...
PPAP did not, however, aim to achieve efficiency at the expense of all else.
methods.inference_reasoning: The Discussion presents detailed time-saving estimates comparing FAIMS workflow to previous TRAP workflow, but the comparison methodology is not documented. Triggers show: (1) authors draw on previous project experience (TRAP 2008-2011), (2) specific time estimates provided (2-3 hours/day, 1 hour/day, 0.5 day/week), (3) comparison across multiple workflow components, (4) estimates qualified as not pursuing efficiency at all costs. This implies a method for retrospective efficiency comparison, but the basis for estimates (timing studies, logs, memory, etc.) and comparison methodology are not documented in Methods.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: Efficiency comparison method not documented: data collection approach for time estimates, comparison methodology, baseline workflow documentation, estimation procedures, uncertainty quantification
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Cannot assess reliability of efficiency claims or verify comparison methodology rigor

methods.method_purpose: To evaluate workflow efficiency improvements from fully digital system compared to hybrid approach
expected_information_missing: Data sources for estimates (logs, surveys, memory)

protocols.protocol_text: Automatic bi-directional incremental synchronization protocol: devices detect server, send changes, receive consolidated data, achieve complete database replication
protocols.verbatim_quote: Opportunistic, incremental, bi-directional synchronization is automatic. When a device detects its server (either local or online), it sends all changes made since last synchronization to the server. The server then integrates those data and returns an up-to-date copy to other devices when they connect. At the end of the process, each device has a complete copy of the database and media (multimedia synchronization can be made unidirectional to save storage space on devices).
protocol_steps: Device sends all changes since last sync
Server returns updated data to requesting device
Other devices sync when they connect
All devices achieve complete database copy

protocols.protocol_text: Daily data export protocol: export synchronized data to CSV and shapefile formats for review, planning, and sharing
protocols.verbatim_quote: Such synchronization was also a prerequisite for daily data export as tabular (CSV) and geospatial (Shapefile; KML) files, which allowed project leaders to plan subsequent work, target locations for additional investigation, inform other decisions, and share data with external collaborators.

protocols.protocol_text: Feature Recording module adaptation protocol: expand controlled vocabularies, add GPS multi-point capability, test functionality, load maps, document workflow
protocols.verbatim_quote: The controlled vocabulary for "feature type" was expanded to include features we expected to encounter based on previous experience and published research ("wall," "cistern," "artifact scatter," etc.). The ability to collect multiple GPS points per feature was also added in order to accommodate more complex feature shapes. After implementing these changes, we tested module functionality, performance, interaction with sensors, synchronization, and export formats. Finally, we loaded local maps and satellite images and documented the recommended field workflow. Adaptation of the existing module took approximately 53 person-hours over five days
protocol_steps: Expand controlled vocabulary for feature types
Load local maps and satellite images

protocols.protocol_text: Gridded Survey module deployment protocol: test pre-existing prototype module without modification in parallel with Feature Recording module
protocols.verbatim_quote: Also in 2017, undergraduate programmers working for FAIMS built a demonstration module for systematic survey. This module reconceptualized the paper forms used by TRAP for field survey in Bulgaria during 2009–2011 and aimed to test FAIMS Mobile's performance and UI against a demanding field workflow. This "Gridded Survey" module had not previously been used in the field. It was deployed by PPAP without modification in the same five-day timeframe as Feature Recording

protocols.protocol_text: Server-based module instantiation protocol: upload definition files via web interface, specify metadata, validate files, populate user lists and vocabularies

location.section: FAIMS Mobile deployment - Module instantiation on a server

protocols.verbatim_quote: Module instantiation involves uploading the definition files to the server via this interface, then specifying module- and project-level metadata ... The "Upload Module" button allows a user to upload a compressed folder containing all definition files in tar.gz format. Alternatively, pressing the "Create Module" button opens a page where each definition file can be uploaded individually. Once definition files are validated and the module instantiated, its name will appear in the module list.

protocols.protocol_text: Device module installation protocol: install FAIMS Mobile from Google Play, connect to server, download module, work offline after installation

location.section: FAIMS Mobile deployment - Module instantiation on mobile devices

protocols.verbatim_quote: Once per device, a user installs FAIMS Mobile from Google Play. Upon first launch, the application is connected to an online demonstration server with example modules and must be reconnected to the project-specific local server or online server ... Since PPAP employed a local server, users connected a device by joining the server's network, opening the application, then selecting "Auto-Discover Server" or entering the server's IP address from "Settings" in Android's "overflow menu" (three stacked dots). Once connected to a server, users see a list of available modules. Modules on the server can be installed or updated on the device by tapping them. Once a module is loaded on the device, data can be collected without a connection to the server.
protocol_steps: Install FAIMS Mobile from Google Play
Auto-discover server or enter IP address

protocols.protocol_text: On-device validation protocol: press Validate button to check required fields, receive immediate feedback on missing data, supply missing information before proceeding
protocols.verbatim_quote: Each module was equipped with a prominent "Validate" button, also available in the application drawer ... When pressed, this button either listed all required fields in the current record that remained empty or displayed an "All fields contain valid data!" message ... Required fields included GPS coordinates, device photo, and basic measurements. Validation to ensure required fields are not empty can be invoked quickly in a module's XML definition file. On-device validation was popular with fieldworkers, as it immediately confirmed that all necessary data had been collected.
protocol_steps: Display missing fields OR success message
Fieldworker supplies missing data if needed

protocols.protocol_text: Daily spatial data digitization protocol: export feature data to GIS, digitize survey unit polygons using GPS points and unit parameters, review spatial accuracy
protocols.verbatim_quote: Each day, we plotted spatial data exported from the Feature Recording module in a desktop GIS (QGIS), where features were reviewed. Gridded Survey data were also exported to the GIS, where project participants drew polygons using the starting GPS point as an anchor, and walker number, row count, and walker/count interval as parameters defining the size of each survey unit polygon. This shape creation was supplemented by points from handheld GPS receivers if necessary. Survey unit polygons were digitized immediately upon return from the field in order to ensure accurate representation of teams' progress and took about 30 minutes per team each day.
protocol_steps: Draw survey unit polygons using GPS anchor points
Apply walker number and interval parameters
Supplement with handheld GPS points if needed

protocols.protocol_text: Feature Recording comprehensive workflow protocol: login, initialize GPS, navigate to known features using maps, create record, document coordinates/dimensions/photos/condition through cooperative team recording, validate completeness
protocols.verbatim_quote: At the start of each day, the user operating the tablet would log in, confirm the "Next Feature ID" value on the device, and either initialize the internal GPS or connect to an external GPS. The team then navigated to the first feature of the day using the historical map, topographic map, and satellite image available via the Map tab. Each team worked within a separate target area to avoid duplicate recordings. Previously recorded features were visible in the Map tab, and associated data were available. Once at a feature, the "Create New Record" button would be pressed and the team would work through the tabs of the Feature tabgroup ... The recording was done cooperatively, with everyone on the team contributing observations and reviewing content.
protocol_steps: Work through General tab (photos, description, setting)
Record Additional GPS points if needed
(from P001) Take photographs (device and digital camera)
(from P001) Note changes from legacy record

parameters.work_pattern: target areas to avoid duplicate recording

consolidation_metadata.rationale: P011 (detailed daily workflow) subsumes P001 (core feature recording steps). P011 describes the complete operational workflow including all steps from P001: navigation, GPS recording, dimensions, photos, condition assessment. Consolidation eliminates redundancy while preserving all procedural detail. Both quotes maintained to show coverage.
consolidation_metadata.source_notes: P011 verbatim quote retained as primary. P001 steps verified present in P011 workflow.

protocols.protocol_text: Gridded Survey comprehensive workflow protocol: teams of 5 walk 25m×25m units in 5m-spaced transects, recording artifact counts every 5m in 5m×5m cells, with team leader digital recording via Walker Grid interface
protocols.verbatim_quote: After logging in and activating the GPS receiver, the team leader opened the Walkers tab, added each team member, and ordered them according to their position. She then defined environmental and administrative defaults for the unit in the Main tab. As the leader completed these preliminary tasks, other members took their positions and prepared for their assigned roles ... When the team was ready to begin, the leader pressed the "Add New Survey Unit" button, which opened the Survey Unit tab and prepopulated it with information inherited from the Main tab, then recorded the starting GPS point. She then switched to the Walker Cells tab and pressed the Walker Grid button ... The team walked in unison at approximately 1 m/s. At the designated 5 m counting interval, the team briefly stopped. The first walker then called out a count or density for each artifact type, which the leader entered into the form associated with that grid cell. After counts were entered for the first walker, the leader pressed the "Next Cell" button
protocol_steps: Open Walkers tab and add team members
Set environmental defaults in Main tab
(from P002) Team of 5 walkers space 5m apart
(from P002) Each walker observes 2m wide swath
(from P002) Walkers call out artifact observations
Press Next Cell after each walker
(from P002) Record environmental conditions at unit start
Press Next Row to advance rows
(from P002) Collect and bag diagnostic artifacts
Compute artifact counts at unit end

consolidation_metadata.rationale: P012 (detailed daily workflow) subsumes P002 (core survey methodology). P012 describes the complete operational workflow including all methodological specifications from P002: team size (5), walker spacing (5m), unit size (25×25m), observation interval (5m), cell size (5×5m), observation swath (2m). Consolidation eliminates redundancy while preserving all parameters and procedural detail.
consolidation_metadata.source_notes: P012 verbatim quote retained as primary. P002 parameters verified present in P012 workflow.

protocols.protocol_text: End-of-day synchronization protocol: return to base, connect devices to chargers and wifi, login, enable sync, wait for completion, verify data on server
protocols.verbatim_quote: At the end of the day, teams would return to base, connect all devices to chargers, join them to the server's wifi network, open the application, log in, and initiate synchronization by pressing the "Enable Sync" button in the overflow menu in the app bar. Bi-directional, incremental synchronization across all devices generally took a few minutes for the Gridded Survey module, which contained only text and structured data, and somewhat longer for the Feature Recording module, which often contained many photographs. After synchronization, all records were available on all devices and on the server. Data on the server was continually and automatically backed up to a ruggedized external hard drive. This redundancy, combined with the append-only nature of the database, protected against data loss, made devices interchangeable, and allowed teams to verify and edit one another's data.
protocol_steps: Automatic backup to external hard drive

protocols.protocol_text: Post-fieldwork data cleaning protocol: streamline free-text fields, extract annotations to separate columns, using OpenRefine for ~2 hours of processing
protocols.verbatim_quote: While data exports were sufficient for mapping of results and day-to-day decision-making, some further data cleaning proved necessary before analysis. Fields that relied on free-text entry rather than controlled vocabularies needed streamlining. Annotations attached to particular values needed to be extracted into their own columns (in a CSV file). Since relatively few fields allowed free-text entry for anything aside from notes or descriptions and the consistent structure of annotations simplified their manipulation, data cleaning for the entire Perachora 2020 dataset took approximately two hours using OpenRefine.

protocols.protocol_text: Automated load testing protocol to predict field performance and identify degradation thresholds for mobile application
protocols.verbatim_quote: Automated testing of the Gridded Survey module suggested that performance would degrade between 50 and 200 units or ca. 30,000–120,000 values (see Supplemental Material 4). The assumptions built into the tests were too pessimistic, however, and we were able to collect around 230 survey unit records (> 135,000 values) before one device became unstable.
protocol_steps: Run automated load tests on module
Compare predictions with actual field performance

protocols.protocol_text: Device malfunction recovery protocol: restart unstable device, resume data collection on same or different device, rely on synchronization for data integrity
trigger_text: we were able to collect around 230 survey unit records (> 135,000 values) before one device became unstable. This malfunction required a restart, but no data were lost.

The device was used for the remainder of the day but continued to perform poorly. Data successfully synchronized in the evening. The remaining 55 survey units were recorded using other tablets, as bi-directional synchronization allowed seamless replacement of any device at any time.
protocols.inference_reasoning: The paper describes device malfunction and recovery but does not document the recovery protocol. Triggers show: (1) device became unstable requiring restart, (2) device continued to be used despite poor performance, (3) data synchronized successfully, (4) remaining work completed on other devices. This implies a protocol for handling device failures, but no procedure is documented in Methods section for device troubleshooting, deciding when to switch devices, or ensuring data integrity during recovery.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: Device failure recovery procedures not documented: troubleshooting steps, decision criteria for device replacement, data integrity verification after malfunction
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Cannot assess whether data loss risks were properly managed during device failures, or whether recovery procedures were systematic vs ad-hoc

procedure_steps: (inferred) Decide to switch to alternate device

protocols.protocol_text: Bluetooth GPS connectivity troubleshooting protocol: detect connection loss, switch from external to internal GPS, accept reduced accuracy to maintain data collection
trigger_text: On Nvidia Shield tablets, the Gridded Survey module also tended to lose connectivity with external Bluetooth GPS, a device-specific bug that we were unable to fix in the field. Internal GPS was used instead, introducing a slightly larger spatial error and reducing device battery life.
protocols.inference_reasoning: The paper describes Bluetooth GPS connectivity problems and the solution (switching to internal GPS) but does not document the troubleshooting protocol. The trigger shows: (1) connectivity loss occurred, (2) problem identified as device-specific bug, (3) field fix attempted but unsuccessful, (4) fallback to internal GPS implemented, (5) trade-offs accepted (reduced accuracy, battery life). This implies a protocol for diagnosing GPS problems, attempting fixes, and implementing fallback solutions, but no such procedure is documented in Methods.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: GPS troubleshooting procedures not documented: diagnostic steps, fallback decision criteria, accuracy trade-off thresholds, battery management strategies
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Cannot assess whether GPS problems were systematically diagnosed and resolved, or how spatial accuracy requirements were balanced against operational constraints

procedure_steps: (inferred) Decide to use internal GPS instead
expected_information_missing: Decision criteria for fallback to internal GPS

protocols.protocol_text: Diagnostic artifact collection and labeling protocol: collect diagnostic artifacts during survey, bag and label samples, link to digital records via identifiers
trigger_text: Separate counts or densities of major artifact types (e.g., pottery, tile, worked stone, etc.) were announced where possible. At the start of each unit, walkers would report environmental conditions (e.g., land use, slope, surface visibility). At the end of the unit, they would bag and label any diagnostic artifacts they had collected.

Such samples were bagged and tagged. The leader noted the presence of a sample in the Survey Unit tab ... updated any data that proved inaccurate, and characterized the chronology and condition of artifacts.
protocols.inference_reasoning: The paper mentions collecting, bagging, and labeling diagnostic artifacts multiple times but never documents the protocol. Triggers show: (1) diagnostic artifacts collected during survey, (2) bagging and labeling occurred at unit end, (3) sample presence recorded in digital system, (4) artifact characteristics documented. This implies a systematic sample collection and labeling protocol, including label content, linking to digital records, and tracking procedures, but these operational details are not documented in Methods.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: Artifact collection protocol not documented: selection criteria for diagnostic artifacts, labeling standards, linking procedure between physical samples and digital records, tracking and storage procedures
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Cannot assess artifact sampling strategy rigor, or verify physical-digital linkage integrity for sample provenance

procedure_steps: (inferred) Record sample presence in digital system

protocols.protocol_text: Server-side validation protocol: apply validation rules after synchronization, flag records for review, correct errors while memories fresh
trigger_text: Data can be validated with specified rules on the device at the time of creation or on the server after synchronization.

The Gridded Survey module also used simple server validation rules that marked records for review on both the server and on devices if key fields were null. Such validation at the time of synchronization allowed errors to be corrected while memories were fresh.

Synchronization was fully automated and required no further configuration or intervention on the part of the user except in rare cases of conflict when more than one user edited the same record while offline; conflicting edits like these were flagged on the server for manual reconciliation.
protocols.inference_reasoning: The paper mentions server-side validation multiple times but never documents the validation protocol in detail. Triggers show: (1) validation occurs after synchronization, (2) rules flag records with null key fields, (3) flagged records marked for review, (4) conflicts identified and flagged for manual reconciliation, (5) errors corrected while memories fresh. This implies a systematic server-side validation protocol including validation rule specifications, flagging mechanisms, error correction workflows, and conflict resolution procedures, but operational details are not documented.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: Server-side validation protocol not documented: specific validation rules, flagging criteria, error notification procedures, correction workflow, conflict resolution procedures, validation timing
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Cannot assess comprehensiveness of validation rules or systematic nature of error correction procedures

This redundancy, combined with the append-only nature of the database, protected against data loss, made devices interchangeable, and allowed teams to verify and edit one another's data.

protocols.protocol_text: Digital camera photo tracking and linking protocol: record photo numbers from external digital camera, link to device records via notes fields, consolidate during post-processing
trigger_text: During feature recording, teams navigated to known features and made a record that included coordinates, dimensions, photographs (on device and using digital cameras), drawings, and a description of the feature's condition
Notes also accommodated digital camera photo numbers, allowing these photographs to be matched to the record later.

Once server-side validation was completed, data and multimedia were exported from the FAIMS server and stored on a separate file server ... At the end of each day, fieldworkers would return to base, initiate synchronization, download images from digital cameras, and scan any paper records such as plan drawings.

protocols.protocol_text: Local server hardware configuration protocol: configure low-power industrial computer as FAIMS server, set up network, install server software from virtual machine image
trigger_text: In terms of resource constraints, we had little scope for hardware purchases or software development. In addition to project leaders' university-provided laptops, we had access to a low-power industrial computer, basic networking gear, and Android tablets, all purchased for fieldwork in 2015 (Supplemental Material 1).
PPAP used a low-power industrial computer as a local server (see Supplemental Material 1), preconfigured before fieldwork. The server has a web interface available to any device on the network
The server is a Ruby application running under Ubuntu, installed either from a shell script or a virtual machine image supplied by FAIMS.

extraction_notes.section_extracted: Pass 5 RDMAP rationalization COMPLETE. Systematic review of all 32 RDMAP items for consolidation opportunities. Executed 2 protocol consolidations: (1) P001→P011 workflow integration, (2) P002→P012 workflow integration. Both consolidations preserve complete procedural detail while eliminating redundancy. Final RDMAP: 2 designs, 8 methods, 20 protocols = 30 items. Reduction: 6.25% (2 items). Below 15-20% target but appropriate for well-documented technical paper where each item describes distinct procedure. Quality over quantity maintained. All tier assignments verified correct. No consolidation opportunities in designs or methods. Next: Pass 6 validation.
extraction_notes.pass2_completion: Pass 2 rationalization complete. Evidence reduced from 85 to 66 via 16 consolidations (empirical graph analysis). Claims reviewed: all interpretive, no arithmetic removals needed. 5 claims had evidence support added. Total reduction: 19 items (11.6%). Final Pass 2 count: 145 items.
extraction_notes.extraction_strategy: Pass 5 applied assessment compatibility test and workflow integration patterns. Conservative consolidation approach for system implementation paper. Workflow protocols (P011, P012) subsumed corresponding methodology protocols (P001, P002) as they describe the same procedures at different levels of detail. All other protocols describe distinct operational procedures warranting separate assessment. Research designs and methods all represent independent strategic/tactical decisions.
known_uncertainties: Minimal consolidation (6.25%) is below typical 15-20% target but reflects appropriate granularity for technical methods paper
Tier assignments verified correct - no adjustments needed
